turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: We'll hear arguments first this morning in Number 349, United States against Helstoski and the consolidated case.
Mr. Stavis, you may proceed whenever you're ready.

turn.speaker: morton_stavis
turn.label: Mr. Morton Stavis
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice and may it please the Court.
There are two cases here and the 546, our petition, Number 349 of the Solicitor General's petition, the facts in both cases are quite simple.
546 which I will deal with first involve the jurisdiction of the District Court to try this indictment.

And the facts there obviously the indictment itself which charges a member of Congress with taking money and conspiring to take money by introducing bills in Congress, bills which the indictment charges were in fact introduced, and the bills as specifically identified in the indictment.
It is plain from the face of the indictment that the grand jury which found it heard, considered and relied upon proof of the performance of legislative acts.

And while it is not clear from the face of the indictment, it is established in the opinion of Judge Meanor and undisputed that's the indicting grand jury, as the grand jury which handed down this indictment received proofs of the performance of legislative act from the United States attorney not from Mr. Helstoski.

It is also clear and undisputed that while Mr. Helstoski gave legislative materials to earlier grand juries, not the indicting grand jury, he had no reason to believe at the time that he gave such materials that he was the target of the grand jury, and in fact somebody else was thereafter indicted, tried and convicted.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Of course it wouldn't make any difference for your theory if he had, would it?

turn.speaker: morton_stavis
turn.label: Mr. Morton Stavis
turn.text: If he was a target?

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: If he was aware that he was a --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: I knew he was.

turn.speaker: morton_stavis
turn.label: Mr. Morton Stavis
turn.text: It -- to our fundamental theory, it doesn't.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Might have something to do with the waiver.

turn.speaker: morton_stavis
turn.label: Mr. Morton Stavis
turn.text: I don't think it has anything to do with waiver either, but I agree that if our theory is correct that this is a jurisdictional allocation then it wouldn't make any difference at all.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Who was the other person under inquiry, another member of Congress?

turn.speaker: morton_stavis
turn.label: Mr. Morton Stavis
turn.text: No, no somebody who had been employed by the Congressmen some eight years previously, was not then employed and hadn't been employed for many, many years.
Now, our position in 546 is, and you put your finger right on it, that the Court had no jurisdiction to try this indictment.
And if the Court agrees with us and that of course, it doesn't have to reach the evidentiary issues which were involved in 349.

Now, I'm not going to attempt to match the eloquence of this Court and its eight opinions dealing with the Speech and the Debate Clause and review or recant the history of that clause in its meaning in England and in United States.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Mr. Stavis, are you going to get it all to the appealability of Judge Meanor's order by the Government?
I noticed that you attacked it in the Third Circuit but neither party apparently contest it here.
It would seem to me that it is not open and shut that that was an appealable order.

turn.speaker: morton_stavis
turn.label: Mr. Morton Stavis
turn.text: Well, I -- we -- in the Third Circuit, we certainly didn't believe that it was an appealable order.
We moved to dismiss before the Third Circuit on those grounds.
The Third Circuit denied our motion.
I must confess that we did not cross-petition on that particular issue, but it may very well be appropriate for the Court to address that question on its own motion because --

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Well, we have jurisdiction of the Court of Appeals opinion -- judgment only if it was properly in the Court of Appeals.

turn.speaker: morton_stavis
turn.label: Mr. Morton Stavis
turn.text: I don't think this matter is properly in the Court of Appeals.

Candidly, I don't think the issue which the Government presented in its petition or even properly before this Court, because the entire factual foundation for the Government's petition in 349 is a series of proposed profers of proof which they asked the District Court to rule upon three times.
And the District Court refused to do so.
So there are no facts before this Court.
And 349 is a wholly and an entirely supposititious case.

And in that respect, I guess I don't have to call to your attention, the attention of the Court, the dissenting opinion by Mr. Justice Blackmun concurred in by the Chief Justice only last week in the (Inaudible) case, which you addressed the question of the proposition that this Court ought -- to be handling supposititious cases.
You get enough business handling concrete issues, and while the other seven members of the Court didn't agree that that principle applied to that case.
There's no question that this Court ordinarily tries and adjudicates only concrete cases.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Well that I get -- that's a case in controversy argument, but did I understand Mr. Stavis, you're suggesting that even though you did not cross-petition on the question of the appealability of the order to the Third Circuit that it's jurisdictional and therefore that we can reach and decide it?

turn.speaker: morton_stavis
turn.label: Mr. Morton Stavis
turn.text: I accepted the suggestion of Mr. Justice Rehnquist in that respect.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: I just want to be clear, that's -- now the arguments you're now making is really a case of controversy, are you (Voice Overlap)?

turn.speaker: morton_stavis
turn.label: Mr. Morton Stavis
turn.text: That's correct.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: And that's a separate argument is it?

turn.speaker: morton_stavis
turn.label: Mr. Morton Stavis
turn.text: That's correct Your Honor.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: All right.

turn.speaker: morton_stavis
turn.label: Mr. Morton Stavis
turn.text: May I get back to the issues in 546 which is the jurisdiction of this Court to try -- of the District Court of an Article III Court to try this indictment.

That the Speech or Debate Clause establishes jurisdictional allocation comes all through the decisions of this Court including its latest, and there of course is the Chief Justice's opinion in Eastland against Servicemen's Union.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: For the Court?

turn.speaker: morton_stavis
turn.label: Mr. Morton Stavis
turn.text: I'm sorry.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Opinion for the Court?

turn.speaker: morton_stavis
turn.label: Mr. Morton Stavis
turn.text: Of course, the opinion for the Court.
And what you addressed there was the fact that the Speech or Debate Clause affects the availability of judicial power.

Now, the corollary to approaching this matter from the point of view of jurisdiction or the availability of judicial power is that no one says that members of Congress are super citizens and Speech or Debate Clause isn't free license to take bribes and commit crimes and introduce bills that are paid for.
That the only question is, which is the proper courthouse?
Is it an Article III Court or is it the Congress of the United States under both the Speech or Debate Clause and the Punishment Clause and so that there is no question about it.
My client never has, does not now nor will he contest the jurisdiction of the Congress of the United States to try the charges which we're involved with here.
Because not exactly looking to be charged by any --

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Can they try these charges now?

turn.speaker: morton_stavis
turn.label: Mr. Morton Stavis
turn.text: I believe so.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: And what sanction could Congress impose?

turn.speaker: morton_stavis
turn.label: Mr. Morton Stavis
turn.text: By way of Kilbourn against Thompson that Congress has complete power to impose any sanctions it chooses including -- if I read Kilbourn against Thompson correctly, imprisonment.
That's what you said in Kilbourn.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: I suppose under the constitution that wouldn't be authorized to impose a cruel or unusual punishment, would it not?

turn.speaker: morton_stavis
turn.label: Mr. Morton Stavis
turn.text: Oh, I think there are constitutional limitations upon the exercise of its power.
That's Powell against McCormack.
We expect that if we act right on this by Congress, we expect to insist upon the due process hearing.
And the whole panoply of rights, that would be applied to any judicial hearing and that would be a judicial hearing.
It's just an exception to Article III jurisdiction, but --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: You going to insist on a jury trial?

turn.speaker: morton_stavis
turn.label: Mr. Morton Stavis
turn.text: No.
No we don't expect to, a jury trial.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Although the constitution guarantees that, isn't it?

turn.speaker: morton_stavis
turn.label: Mr. Morton Stavis
turn.text: Guarantees it, an Article III trial.
I do not believe that it would be --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: I didn't say anything about an Article III trial, does it?

turn.speaker: morton_stavis
turn.label: Mr. Morton Stavis
turn.text: Well, I would guess however that we would accept the fact that would not be a jury trial.
If we would -- if we were entitled a jury trial, we would waive it.
I think the essence of the Punishment Clause is that the Congress itself has that power.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Subject to what constitutional limitations?

turn.speaker: morton_stavis
turn.label: Mr. Morton Stavis
turn.text: Subject to due process limitations.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: But not a jury trial?

turn.speaker: morton_stavis
turn.label: Mr. Morton Stavis
turn.text: That's correct, subject to cruel and unusual punishment limitation.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Presumption of innocence?

turn.speaker: morton_stavis
turn.label: Mr. Morton Stavis
turn.text: Presumption of innocence.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Necessity of proof beyond a reasonable doubt?

turn.speaker: morton_stavis
turn.label: Mr. Morton Stavis
turn.text: I believe so, right of confrontation, right of cross-examination, right of counsel or --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Mr. Stavis, is it clear that their clause applies to a former congressman?

turn.speaker: morton_stavis
turn.label: Mr. Morton Stavis
turn.text: Congress in the past has so asserted, we do not dispute that and besides as of the time that this indictment was found as to Helstoski was a member of Congress.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Yes but he's not now, any punishment by a Congressman -- by Congress would be from now on.

turn.speaker: morton_stavis
turn.label: Mr. Morton Stavis
turn.text: That is correct and we do not dispute the jurisdiction of Congress but the point that I'm making is --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Well, you do it here because you don't have to.

turn.speaker: morton_stavis
turn.label: Mr. Morton Stavis
turn.text: That is correct, and all -- all we have to dispute here is the jurisdiction of the Article III Court.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: And Courts don't have any jurisdiction.

turn.speaker: morton_stavis
turn.label: Mr. Morton Stavis
turn.text: And at the time this indictment was found, Congress clearly had jurisdiction.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: What would it -- does it -- is there a statute of limitations on this?

turn.speaker: morton_stavis
turn.label: Mr. Morton Stavis
turn.text: I don't know that there is any.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Well Mr. Stavis, what took -- you said Congress has asserted authority to try after his defeat which I gather is what happened to this congressman.

turn.speaker: morton_stavis
turn.label: Mr. Morton Stavis
turn.text: That's correct.
In --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Has that ever happened?

turn.speaker: morton_stavis
turn.label: Mr. Morton Stavis
turn.text: Yes it has.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Against whom?

turn.speaker: morton_stavis
turn.label: Mr. Morton Stavis
turn.text: Well, Mr. Brand speaking for the speaker --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Oh, I see --

turn.speaker: morton_stavis
turn.label: Mr. Morton Stavis
turn.text: -- will address that particular question.Historically, it has occurred.

I think in fact it occurred in the most famous corruption investigation by the Congress in the Crédit Mobilier transaction where Congressman Oakes Ames was charged, tried and convicted but it has -- after he was no longer sitting.
And I think there are a number of other examples of that sort.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Mr. Stavis, would the net result of accepting your theory mean that Congress could not enact and the President sign a law making it a criminal offense for a Congressman to take a bribe?

turn.speaker: morton_stavis
turn.label: Mr. Morton Stavis
turn.text: Congress has enacted such a law, and such a law is on -- to that books and has been enforced and is valid, but not in respect to the performance of legislative acts.
In other words, the Johnson case which wasn't in fact tried under that section is a perfect example.
A Congressman takes a bribe to try to influence the Department of Justice, the normal conflict of interest situation or to take in bribe for an act which is not a legislative act in nature.

What the Speech or Debate Clause is driving at is that if you want to try a legislative act for the connection with legislative act if you want to try the legislative process that belongs in the Congress.
If you want to try just the question of bribery, not implicating the legislative process that you may do in an Article III Court.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: But when -- Mr. Stavis, when the charge is for taking money in exchange for a promise of a future act, hasn't the Court held that it's not necessary to show the legislative act or the legislative activity?

turn.speaker: morton_stavis
turn.label: Mr. Morton Stavis
turn.text: And of course that's your opinion in the Brewster case.
That's exactly what the Court held.

And the whole point of the Government's taking this case is that they want to get around that decision, because in that decision, you said at least eight times, we counted them, that under the Brewster indictment you could not show the actual performance of a legislative act.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Well, how will we know whether the Government is going to try to prove that until the case is tried?

turn.speaker: morton_stavis
turn.label: Mr. Morton Stavis
turn.text: Well, that's what we thought accepting that the Government and that's why we don't think you would even consider this case but the Government says, “Please look at our profers of proof, this is really what we want to prove.”
We say, “Those people aren't going to testify that way let alone the fact that if they did testify it wouldn't be true.”
Where the Government is asking you to make -- asking the District Court and asking you to make rulings on advanced evidentiary proof.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: I understand you say you didn't want us to hear this case?

turn.speaker: morton_stavis
turn.label: Mr. Morton Stavis
turn.text: We want you to hear the Government's petition.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Oh, I see.

turn.speaker: morton_stavis
turn.label: Mr. Morton Stavis
turn.text: We want you to hear the Government's petition as --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: I see, I see.

turn.speaker: morton_stavis
turn.label: Mr. Morton Stavis
turn.text: Sure, I want you to hear my petition.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: I see.

turn.speaker: morton_stavis
turn.label: Mr. Morton Stavis
turn.text: Because my petition --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: I just marvel at your fairness.

turn.speaker: morton_stavis
turn.label: Mr. Morton Stavis
turn.text: Well, I don't think it's not -- I think its not any fair but correct.
But let me get back Mr. Chief Justice to your question, because you said that in Brewster and you looked at an indictment that did not charge the performance of legislative acts.
Look at this indictment, on its face it charges the specific performance of designated and named legislative acts.

Now if this case goes to trial, and if you prove -- if the Government is permitted to prove the facts as alleged in this indictment, I'm talking about what would've happened if they came up with a Brewster indictment, but if they proved the facts alleged in this indictment that jury is going to be asked to decide questions as to the functioning of the legislative process specifically.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: What if the trial court excludes any evidence about the legislative acts?

turn.speaker: morton_stavis
turn.label: Mr. Morton Stavis
turn.text: Well that's what Mr.-- that's what Judge Meanor said he was going to do and that's why the Government took this case up.
They weren't unsatisfied with Judge Meanor's decision which said, “I read the Brewster opinion and I intend to enforce it and not permit the introduction of legislative acts.”
The Government took it up that's why this case have been going on now for over two and a half years without a trial.

Now, but I want to emphasize that our position is that in the light of this indictment, the issues just does not end with the fact that the Government would not be permitted to introduce that evidence at trial.
And that's what my petition is about.
I say that the grand jury released and found an indictment which on its face is beyond the jurisdiction of this Court.
And what the Government is saying is, “Well, let's fix up the indictment a little bit.”
Well, maybe they shouldn't have charged and alleged these legislative acts which they designate in that indictment.
“Well, we'll just strike it out.
Fix it up and make it like the Brewster type indictment and forget that it ever happened.”

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Mr. Stavis, do you agree that if they strike the allegations of the specific overt acts describing legislative acts that the indictment would then be comparable to the indictment in the Brewster case?

turn.speaker: morton_stavis
turn.label: Mr. Morton Stavis
turn.text: Before, the morals in this specific legislative act, it's also the allegations in counts 2 (a) and 4 of the indictment which also include allegations of specific legislative acts.
Yes, the answer is if all those words were taken out then you'd have an indictment that read like the Brewster indictment.

But the trouble about doing that is that by the issuance of the indictment the executive branch of the government, the Executive Branch of the Government has implicated -- Judge (Inaudible) and the grand jury has implicated and impugned the functioning of Congress.
Now the point that we make is that when the Speech or Debate Clause is set up to protect this delicate tripartite separation of powers, it means that the --

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: But Mr. Stavis, would you say then that if before the defendant is put in jeopardy, the def -- the Government can come in and voluntarily dismiss the indictment, that permission to dismiss the indictment then reindict it leaving out all the references to legislative acts?

turn.speaker: morton_stavis
turn.label: Mr. Morton Stavis
turn.text: No problem about that.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Well, if they still --

turn.speaker: morton_stavis
turn.label: Mr. Morton Stavis
turn.text: The (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: -- would've done what you just said.

turn.speaker: morton_stavis
turn.label: Mr. Morton Stavis
turn.text: No, provided that now this is the difference, provided that it had not presented the legislative acts to the grand jury.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: So that having presented the legislative acts to the grand jury that he have given him permanent immunity?

turn.speaker: morton_stavis
turn.label: Mr. Morton Stavis
turn.text: No, they haven't.
There's nothing in the world that says that they can't (Voice Overlap) the grand jury and present a case to another grand jury that's exactly what happened in the Long case.
In the Long case decided by this Court --

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Well your position then just so I get is that having told a particular grand jury about a legislative act by a Congressman, that grand jury may never return an indictment against that Congressman?

turn.speaker: morton_stavis
turn.label: Mr. Morton Stavis
turn.text: Indictment which charges legislative acts.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Well, --

turn.speaker: morton_stavis
turn.label: Mr. Morton Stavis
turn.text: I mean -- of course they (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: I thought you said that in a moment ago if they dismissed the indictment and brought a new one would -- didn't make reference, its still be bad?

turn.speaker: morton_stavis
turn.label: Mr. Morton Stavis
turn.text: Oh no!
No, what I mean is that they can't -- I mean obviously they can indict him for bank robbery, something having -- they may be able to indict him for bank robbery having --

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: No, they just excised from the new indictment any reference to the legislative acts and they merely follow the pattern of the Brewster indictment.

turn.speaker: morton_stavis
turn.label: Mr. Morton Stavis
turn.text: That would be invalid because the grand jury, the grand jury has violated the Speech or Debate Clause but this is not to say that the Government cannot convene another grand jury, present the case which does not involve proof of legislative acts and come out with the Brewster type indictment.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Well but that's like Calandra.
Once the information has been presented to the grand jury there's nothing more that can be done to salvage the Speech or Debate Clause.
The question is whether the indictment it returns is constitutional or not.
The idea that if you present a different information to another grand jury, somehow you could call it back to -- call the earlier proceedings back just isn't possible.

turn.speaker: morton_stavis
turn.label: Mr. Morton Stavis
turn.text: It is not like Calandra.
Calandra is a very different kind of a case.
In Calandra you decided that under the Fourth Amendment -- the exclusionary clause which is your making that you would allow a grand jury to hear evidence unlawfully seized by somebody else.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: And we also said in Calandra that the right of privacy protected by the Fourth Amendment had already been breached and there was nothing that --

turn.speaker: morton_stavis
turn.label: Mr. Morton Stavis
turn.text: I understand that.
But here you have an explicit provision of the speech -- in the constitution which says that speech or debate, which I wish would mean legislative acts, shall not be questioned in any other place.
In Gravel you said that includes a grand jury.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Did it say he may not be questioned or he may not be required to answer?

turn.speaker: morton_stavis
turn.label: Mr. Morton Stavis
turn.text: Says he may not be questioned.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: And, he may not --

turn.speaker: morton_stavis
turn.label: Mr. Morton Stavis
turn.text: I think it says may not be questioned.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: No.
Now, did he have to respond to anything in the grand jury?

turn.speaker: morton_stavis
turn.label: Mr. Morton Stavis
turn.text: I think he did at the point when he wasn't the target.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: I read -- as I read Gravel --Well, a lot of non-targets, witnesses before a grand jury has claimed immunity from responding for various reasons, do they not?

turn.speaker: morton_stavis
turn.label: Mr. Morton Stavis
turn.text: On the Fifth Amendment ground.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Yes, but there might be another reason here then, wouldn't there?

turn.speaker: morton_stavis
turn.label: Mr. Morton Stavis
turn.text: It might be but if I read the Gravel case accurately and I think I do, there is no speech or debate protection from questioning when the grand jury is investigating third party crime.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Well Mr. Stavis, am I right that your client voluntarily gave the legislative count to the grand jury?

turn.speaker: morton_stavis
turn.label: Mr. Morton Stavis
turn.text: Has laid it to them voluntarily and --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: So is that -- do you take position that if a Congressman is up for anything and he voluntarily gives a legislative thing, he can't be indicted from then on.

turn.speaker: morton_stavis
turn.label: Mr. Morton Stavis
turn.text: --He must --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: -- he is immunized forever?

turn.speaker: morton_stavis
turn.label: Mr. Morton Stavis
turn.text: He wasn't up for anything.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Yes, but he voluntarily didn't he, he did?

turn.speaker: morton_stavis
turn.label: Mr. Morton Stavis
turn.text: He was subpoenaed to testify.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Did he?
But didn't he bring these bills there?

turn.speaker: morton_stavis
turn.label: Mr. Morton Stavis
turn.text: He was subpoenaed to testify --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: And didn't he bring the bills there?

turn.speaker: morton_stavis
turn.label: Mr. Morton Stavis
turn.text: That is correct.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Didn't he bring the legislative matters there?

turn.speaker: morton_stavis
turn.label: Mr. Morton Stavis
turn.text: That is correct.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: And now he complains about bringing them there?

turn.speaker: morton_stavis
turn.label: Mr. Morton Stavis
turn.text: Because he believes --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: And now he complains about bringing them there?

turn.speaker: morton_stavis
turn.label: Mr. Morton Stavis
turn.text: He doesn't complain about bringing them there --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Oh, what is he complaining about?

turn.speaker: morton_stavis
turn.label: Mr. Morton Stavis
turn.text: -- he thinks he was acquired to bring them there.
He doesn't complain about that at all.
What he complains about is some grand jury that he never brought them before and which turned the wheel and targeted him.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: He would be immunized and we're all going to bank in to the State of Alaska.

turn.speaker: morton_stavis
turn.label: Mr. Morton Stavis
turn.text: Your Honor, I've said exactly the contrary.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: I'm not too sure you wouldn't go so far to say he'd be immunized from robbing a bank in Great Britain.

turn.speaker: morton_stavis
turn.label: Mr. Morton Stavis
turn.text: Your Honor I said exactly the contrary.
I say that quite the contrary, he is subject to prosecution in an Article III Court by a grand jury which doesn't have this material.
He is subject to prosecution before Congress where this material may properly be the subject of inquiry by the Court which has jurisdiction.
So I do not accept the suggestion Your Honor because I think I've said exactly the contrary.
May I reserve some of my time --

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Does it not sometimes happen, Mr. Stavis that the prosecution fails to prove all of what is alleged in an indictment and yet a conviction nevertheless results?

turn.speaker: morton_stavis
turn.label: Mr. Morton Stavis
turn.text: Of course it -- of course that happens but that those are not cases where you're dealing with an expressed constitutional prescription --

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Well now this trial judge has indicated that he will in advance have the advantage of his statement that he would not admit any testimony on that score --

turn.speaker: morton_stavis
turn.label: Mr. Morton Stavis
turn.text: That he intends to comply with Brewster.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Well --

turn.speaker: morton_stavis
turn.label: Mr. Morton Stavis
turn.text: -- but I just -- our position is that the indictment is already a violation of the Speech or Debate Clause.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: And therefore he can never be tried under this indictment.

turn.speaker: morton_stavis
turn.label: Mr. Morton Stavis
turn.text: Under this indictment.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: And that what -- this indictment has to be dismissed is your opinion?

turn.speaker: morton_stavis
turn.label: Mr. Morton Stavis
turn.text: That's correct.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: And if he's to be indicted, he has to be indicted by a new grand jury which does not hear the evidence that you say violates the Speech and Debate Clause.

turn.speaker: morton_stavis
turn.label: Mr. Morton Stavis
turn.text: And that's not any different than what you did in --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Well, but that is your position?

turn.speaker: morton_stavis
turn.label: Mr. Morton Stavis
turn.text: That is correct, it's precisely this position.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: What about the statute of limitation?

turn.speaker: morton_stavis
turn.label: Mr. Morton Stavis
turn.text: I'm sorry?

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: What about the statute of limitation?

turn.speaker: morton_stavis
turn.label: Mr. Morton Stavis
turn.text: I think there's an expressed provision of the statutes which provides that where an indictment is voided for some reason not having to do with the merits of the offense that the statute of limitations is told I think there's an expressed provision in the United States Code.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Well, (Voice Overlap) where it is?

turn.speaker: morton_stavis
turn.label: Mr. Morton Stavis
turn.text: No, but I'll be glad to furnish it to --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: If you give me an idea, I can find it, can you give me an idea.

turn.speaker: morton_stavis
turn.label: Mr. Morton Stavis
turn.text: It's in the United States Code.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Good.

turn.speaker: morton_stavis
turn.label: Mr. Morton Stavis
turn.text: But there's an expressed provision -- I'll looked that up thinking about this case and I did look it up.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: In fact you can't -- didn't remember it, makes me think it might not help you (Inaudible).

turn.speaker: morton_stavis
turn.label: Mr. Morton Stavis
turn.text: Well, it doesn't help me in the sense that in an indictment, a new indictment can be brought as I have suggested.In that sense it doesn't help me, but also makes clear that the suggestion I've made as to the potentialities of a new indictment is entirely feasible.
And I just want to say in reference to Mr. Justice Brennan's question, that of course is exactly what you do in an immunity case.
You forbid the use of immunized testimony.
You impose upon the prosecutor an obligation to establish that he didn't use immunized testimony when he got the indictment.
If he can't make it he can go to another grand jury.
He can go to another grand jury and get an indictment without the use of the immunized testimony, does that all the time.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Is there any case from this Court saying that an indictment returned where that the Government didn't show was not based on immunized testimony is invalid?

turn.speaker: morton_stavis
turn.label: Mr. Morton Stavis
turn.text: I think Warren comes close to that.
In Warren what you said was --

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Well, I -- could you ask -- answer yes or no?

turn.speaker: morton_stavis
turn.label: Mr. Morton Stavis
turn.text: I'm not sure I could put my fingers on a case at the moment.
May I reserve some time?

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Very well --

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: May I ask you --

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: -- Mr. Stavis.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: -- one question before you do.

You mentioned the jurisdictional for former members would be covered in your colleague's argument, but as I look at his brief, he gives us some example of five former members over whom Congress say they did not have jurisdiction?
Maybe he will cover it, but I would like to be advised on that if it's incorrect.

turn.speaker: morton_stavis
turn.label: Mr. Morton Stavis
turn.text: I think he's given an example of cases in which former members of Congress were covered.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: You don't happen to know such a case yourself?

turn.speaker: morton_stavis
turn.label: Mr. Morton Stavis
turn.text: Other than the Oakes Ames case which I mentioned.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: What was the bank in Grand City --

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Could you give me that again, the --

turn.speaker: morton_stavis
turn.label: Mr. Morton Stavis
turn.text: Oakes Ames, Congressman --

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Congressman Ames?

turn.speaker: morton_stavis
turn.label: Mr. Morton Stavis
turn.text: Congressman Ames involved in the Crédit Mobilier controversy around the 1870's I think.
That was the biggest scandal case in Congress at the time.
Thank you very much.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Mr. Brand.

turn.speaker: stanley_mbrand
turn.label: Mr. Stanley M.Brand
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice, and may it please the Court.

I'm here representing the Honorable Thomas P.O'Neil, Speaker, the Honorable Frank Thompson, Chairman and the Honorable William Dickenson, ranking minority member Committee on House Administration of the U.S. House of Representatives as amici curiae.T
he interest of the speaker and his colleagues in this case is apparent.
It presents serious questions in our minds as to the continued viability of the Speech or Debate Clause.
At the outset, I would like to make one point clear.
The Congress has read Johnson and Brewster and that Congress accepts Johnson and Brewster.
When we saw the Solicitor's petition however, and what we viewed as an attempt to relitigate Brewster, we were concerned, and that's why we are here.

To paraphrase Thomas Jefferson's characterization of the clause which he wrote shortly after the adoption of the constitution, “The clause is intended to protect the substance rather than the shadow of representative government, and for that reason it states for any speech or debate they shall not be questioned in any other place.”
We believe that this clause operates as an institutional protection as well as a personalized privilege.
And to affect this high principle of an unfettered legislative branch, the framers concluded that a jurisdictional allocation was necessary.
And we read this jurisdictional allocation from the Speech or Debate Clause read together with the Punishment Clause.
Like other jurisdictional requirements, the trial of legislative acts must occur in a proper forum.
It is not subject to waiver, Congressman Helstoski cannot waive himself into an Article III Court for the trial of legislative acts.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: That is even if he had voluntarily submitted all this material --

turn.speaker: stanley_mbrand
turn.label: Mr. Stanley M.Brand
turn.text: That's right.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: -- regarding his legislative act.

turn.speaker: stanley_mbrand
turn.label: Mr. Stanley M.Brand
turn.text: That's our position.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: And even that --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Even if he admit an unequivocal explicit waiver, knowing waiver voluntarily?

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Yes, any more than two --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: He was just --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: -- any more than two litigants --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: -- not empowered to waive.

turn.speaker: stanley_mbrand
turn.label: Mr. Stanley M.Brand
turn.text: -- any more than two litigants could present themselves to an Article III Court --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: And (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: stanley_mbrand
turn.label: Mr. Stanley M.Brand
turn.text: -- without a case of controversy and say, “We would like the Court nevertheless to try this case.”

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: In other words, the Speech or Debate Clause doesn't belong to an individual, it belongs to an institution, is that your point?

turn.speaker: stanley_mbrand
turn.label: Mr. Stanley M.Brand
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Well couldn't --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well if it does, why can't that institution provide for its waiver?

turn.speaker: stanley_mbrand
turn.label: Mr. Stanley M.Brand
turn.text: Because the clause is a protection for the member as well even as against --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: So it's both?

turn.speaker: stanley_mbrand
turn.label: Mr. Stanley M.Brand
turn.text: -- a hostile Congress.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: So it's both?

turn.speaker: stanley_mbrand
turn.label: Mr. Stanley M.Brand
turn.text: That's correct.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Neither one can waiver --

turn.speaker: stanley_mbrand
turn.label: Mr. Stanley M.Brand
turn.text: It protects unpopular members as well as popular members --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: So that --

turn.speaker: stanley_mbrand
turn.label: Mr. Stanley M.Brand
turn.text: -- Democrats as well as Republicans.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: So Congress cannot by however narrow a piece of legislation --

turn.speaker: stanley_mbrand
turn.label: Mr. Stanley M.Brand
turn.text: That's right.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: -- provide for the --

turn.speaker: stanley_mbrand
turn.label: Mr. Stanley M.Brand
turn.text: Any --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: -- for the executive prosecution of a legislative act.

turn.speaker: stanley_mbrand
turn.label: Mr. Stanley M.Brand
turn.text: That's right, any more than we could delegate impeachment for instance.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Mr. Brand, Congress I assume could amend the 201 and the other bribery statute and say, “They do not apply to Congressmen.”

turn.speaker: stanley_mbrand
turn.label: Mr. Stanley M.Brand
turn.text: They could do that.
Our position would be --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Well, aren't you now doing that?

turn.speaker: stanley_mbrand
turn.label: Mr. Stanley M.Brand
turn.text: No sir, we don't believe we are.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Well, aren't you trying to get us to do that?

turn.speaker: stanley_mbrand
turn.label: Mr. Stanley M.Brand
turn.text: I don't think so.
What we're saying is as you said in Brewster, these cases can go forward without impugning legislative acts, and that's what we are saying here.
The residuent --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Do you challenge the indictments Mr. Brand or just the evidentiary problem?

turn.speaker: stanley_mbrand
turn.label: Mr. Stanley M.Brand
turn.text: We do.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: You agree with Mr. Stavis --

turn.speaker: stanley_mbrand
turn.label: Mr. Stanley M.Brand
turn.text: We do in this case.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: stanley_mbrand
turn.label: Mr. Stanley M.Brand
turn.text: Although we agree also that there is nothing to prevent the U.S. attorney from taking the non-legislative material presenting it to a new grand jury and indicting and going forward to trial.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Except maybe the statute of limitations.

turn.speaker: stanley_mbrand
turn.label: Mr. Stanley M.Brand
turn.text: If that in fact is a problem.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: But you would -- in that new indictment or in those new grand jury proceedings or in the subsequent trial, the evidence the Government now proposes to use you would say would be unusable?

turn.speaker: stanley_mbrand
turn.label: Mr. Stanley M.Brand
turn.text: Correct.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Hasn't Congress or didn't Congress take quite a long step in relation to the Speech or Debate Clause when they enacted these provisions?

turn.speaker: stanley_mbrand
turn.label: Mr. Stanley M.Brand
turn.text: I don't think so Your Honor, 201 like a plethora of other statutes regulating non-legislative behavior has been passed by Congress in that context.
We have statutes for instance, 18 U.S.C. 431 says that a member may not enter into a contract in which the United States is a party.
That's not a legislative act, we regulate that by statute.

We regulate campaign financing, because we say that when a member takes a political contribution or campaigns for office, he is not engaging in the legislative process and we regulate that through the United States Code.

I don't believe you can read 201 in the context of the U.S. Code in the other ways in which we regulate members Congress -- conduct as the one example where we have attempted to put into Article III Courts the trial of legislative acts.
I don't believe that's consistent with the design of the Code at this time.
At this point we come to the question of the indictment.
We would say that there having been neither a waiver nor a delegation under 201.
The indictment at issue here which charges legislative acts on the basis of what the grand jury heard is fatally defective.
And we say this for several reasons.
This is not Calandra and the Fourth Amendment.
This is not Costello and the Fifth Amendment.

This is the Speech or Debate Clause which is part of the constitution, which the framers placed in the constitution to protect questioning at the earliest possible juncture, not after indictment when the death blow has been dealt as in this case.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Well, to prevent question anywhere in any other place?

turn.speaker: stanley_mbrand
turn.label: Mr. Stanley M.Brand
turn.text: Correct.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: But why wouldn't your interest be served by according to Congressman a right to assert before the grand jury the privilege that you're talking about now?

turn.speaker: stanley_mbrand
turn.label: Mr. Stanley M.Brand
turn.text: Our position would not -- denying that.
The --

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: But --

turn.speaker: stanley_mbrand
turn.label: Mr. Stanley M.Brand
turn.text: -- grand jury which indicted him --

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Why wouldn't it be fully served and if he chooses not to assert it, then there is some form of waiver.

turn.speaker: stanley_mbrand
turn.label: Mr. Stanley M.Brand
turn.text: Well, if it's never asserted it never becomes an issue, but in this case the grand jury which ultimately indicted him was one which there could be no waiver because he never appeared before that grand jury.
What we're saying on the indictment issue is that the indictment is defective because the design of the Speech or Debate Clause is to present -- prevent questioning.
If the questioning has already occurred and you are willing to say that we will only at trial put on some evidentiary prescriptions then you have not remedied the potential abuse which exists.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: But what was the questioning before the grand jury which violated the Speech and Debate Clause?

turn.speaker: stanley_mbrand
turn.label: Mr. Stanley M.Brand
turn.text: The legislative acts.
It --

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: To whom were the questions addressed?

turn.speaker: stanley_mbrand
turn.label: Mr. Stanley M.Brand
turn.text: I believe they were directed to the defendant.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Well, but why couldn't he then assert the speech and debate privilege and fully vindicate it by asserting it at that point, and not having done so, he has waived it.

turn.speaker: stanley_mbrand
turn.label: Mr. Stanley M.Brand
turn.text: Well, under Mr. Stavis' formulation and I think we would agree with most of that.
A member must answer as to third party crime before a grand jury.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: But as soon as it reached him, is it not implied in both Johnson and the Brewster case that he not only need not answer, he may assert the proposition that he cannot be questioned.

To give an example, if he were sued in a complaint in a civil case for a libel and the complaint alleged that the libel was committed on the floor of the House, could not the member of Congress simply informally tell the Court by letter or any other way, that he was not going to answer because the Speech or Debate Clause protected him.
And he was not going to appear and that any judgment entered on the basis of that complaint would be a nullity under the Speech or Debate Clause?

turn.speaker: stanley_mbrand
turn.label: Mr. Stanley M.Brand
turn.text: Well as I --

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: So that he -- it is more than a quite matter of not being questioned or not answering, he can't even be questioned, isn't that so?

turn.speaker: stanley_mbrand
turn.label: Mr. Stanley M.Brand
turn.text: That's correct.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Well, but he then submitted to the questioning here.

turn.speaker: stanley_mbrand
turn.label: Mr. Stanley M.Brand
turn.text: Well, wouldn't he be -- would the same situation occur where he never appeared and the U.S. attorney went to the Library of Congress and took the legislative material out off there, is that a questioning?
He would never have appeared to assert the privilege yet we would assert that that's prohibited.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Well, indeed you look --

turn.speaker: stanley_mbrand
turn.label: Mr. Stanley M.Brand
turn.text: That the grand jury can't hear --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: I thought you would assert that even if he appeared and answered freely, nevertheless.

turn.speaker: stanley_mbrand
turn.label: Mr. Stanley M.Brand
turn.text: That's correct, he as a claimant in a Article III Court could come in and claim that he should get a remedy from the Court.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well Mr. Brand, he certainly don't need to -- I know you say that he -- the evidence should never have even been presented to the grand jury, but even if there was -- even if it was properly presented or even if it could be said that he waived in some matter the presentation of the evidence, you still say that he never consented to be indicted.
Never consented to be threatened with indictment and that would of course solve a lot of your problems if you win on that.

turn.speaker: stanley_mbrand
turn.label: Mr. Stanley M.Brand
turn.text: Well again, I believe that the heart of the clause is protection of the Congress from coordinate branches.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: And I gather -- I thought your position was so far does that principle go that nothing that he does before the grand jury can support an indictment.

turn.speaker: stanley_mbrand
turn.label: Mr. Stanley M.Brand
turn.text: Correct.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Nothing, isn't that true?

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Well Mr. Brand, he --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: But can he support a waiver?

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: -- he didn't testify before this grand jury, did he?

turn.speaker: stanley_mbrand
turn.label: Mr. Stanley M.Brand
turn.text: The one that he was indicted by?

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: stanley_mbrand
turn.label: Mr. Stanley M.Brand
turn.text: No, he did not.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: He didn't testify before that grand jury.

turn.speaker: stanley_mbrand
turn.label: Mr. Stanley M.Brand
turn.text: He did not.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: So your position has to be that evidence of legislative acts is inadmissible before the grand jury even though the man itself is --

turn.speaker: stanley_mbrand
turn.label: Mr. Stanley M.Brand
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: But the clause doesn't read that way.
It says that the Congressman shall not be questioned in any other place, it doesn't say the evidence of legislative act shall not be admissible before a grand jury.

turn.speaker: stanley_mbrand
turn.label: Mr. Stanley M.Brand
turn.text: Of course the --

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: That if he -- mentioned even acknowledged with third party crime evidence of legislative act shall be --

turn.speaker: stanley_mbrand
turn.label: Mr. Stanley M.Brand
turn.text: Well of course the Court -- the clause doesn't say either that, it is merely that evidence shall not be presented.
We would read “shall not be questioned” to include the questioning of his legislative acts whether or not he is the authoror or not.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Well, he wasn't questioned in the grand jury, was he?

turn.speaker: stanley_mbrand
turn.label: Mr. Stanley M.Brand
turn.text: That at time and the grand jury he was not.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: But at the time and grand jury is conducting its investigation, it presumably doesn't have its mind made up what its going to do at the end of the inquiry.

Does it have to stop every time somebody propose and introduced in the -- before it a legislative act and decide whether or not it can be received based on what its ultimately going to decide with respect to whom it may indict?

turn.speaker: stanley_mbrand
turn.label: Mr. Stanley M.Brand
turn.text: But in this case there was the -- a mechanism for calling out the legislative acts by presenting -- the U.S. attorney by presenting them to the -- by not presenting them to the indicting grand jury.
There was a mechanism but it wasn't used.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: May I ask you one other question?
Is it your view that the Congress retains jurisdiction to punish former members?

turn.speaker: stanley_mbrand
turn.label: Mr. Stanley M.Brand
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: And what is your authority for that?

turn.speaker: stanley_mbrand
turn.label: Mr. Stanley M.Brand
turn.text: Well, our authority would be the residual -- the inherent power of the body is punished, contempts committed by its members at the time they were members for conduct which occurred when they were members.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Has the Congress -- is it not true that your brief recites an example of three members or it did not have former members of whom did not have jurisdiction.

turn.speaker: stanley_mbrand
turn.label: Mr. Stanley M.Brand
turn.text: Well, that report raised doubts as to whether there was jurisdiction and those cases against those former members were dropped for other reasons.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: The military once asserted jurisdiction to punish its foreign members too, but it got a negative answer from this Court, didn't it?

turn.speaker: stanley_mbrand
turn.label: Mr. Stanley M.Brand
turn.text: I believe it did.
We're talking again about what we would say is the inherent power of the body to punish members not as private citizens but for conduct which occurred in the body when they were --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: When they were members.

turn.speaker: stanley_mbrand
turn.label: Mr. Stanley M.Brand
turn.text: -- when they were members.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: And that was the military's theory too.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Mr. Stavis indicated that you were going to tell us about the number of Congressmen, former Congressmen punished by the House or the Senate.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Yes.
The House has doubted its authority, it's true as this Court cited in Powell v. McCormack, its authority to expel a member for conduct which occurred before he became a member of Congress.
But it has not doubted its power to punish conduct occurring in a prior Congress.
As was indicated by Mr. Stavis, Oakes Ames --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: By a man who is no longer a member?

turn.speaker: stanley_mbrand
turn.label: Mr. Stanley M.Brand
turn.text: No, in that case he was a member of the 42nd Congress, although --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: So did you say that -- has Congress doubted its power to punish conduct occurring in a former Congress by a man who is no longer a member?

turn.speaker: stanley_mbrand
turn.label: Mr. Stanley M.Brand
turn.text: I'm not sure if there's ever expressed any view on that.Our view of the self disciplinary process as it is evolving at this stage would be that we would have the power to --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Well Mr. Brand is there any instance of a former Congressman tried by the Congress or the House or Senate for a conduct (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: stanley_mbrand
turn.label: Mr. Stanley M.Brand
turn.text: There is none that I can get to.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: There are some?

turn.speaker: stanley_mbrand
turn.label: Mr. Stanley M.Brand
turn.text: See that -- I can cite to none.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, what about -- I thought Mr. Stavis indicated there was an instance, is that right or not?

turn.speaker: stanley_mbrand
turn.label: Mr. Stanley M.Brand
turn.text: Well he talked about the Crédit Mobilierscandal.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, what about that?

turn.speaker: stanley_mbrand
turn.label: Mr. Stanley M.Brand
turn.text: And that was disciplined in the 42nd Congress for what occurred in the 40th.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Of an incumbent Congressman.

turn.speaker: stanley_mbrand
turn.label: Mr. Stanley M.Brand
turn.text: Of an -- sitting member of Congress.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: I see.

turn.speaker: stanley_mbrand
turn.label: Mr. Stanley M.Brand
turn.text: I see that my time is up.
If the Chief Justice would indulge me for one minute I would simply state --

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: You may.

turn.speaker: stanley_mbrand
turn.label: Mr. Stanley M.Brand
turn.text: -- that the self-disciplinary process is an evolving process.
To say that the legislative acts will go unpunished is not correct.
Legislative misbehavior and misconduct is not immunized.
The House has taken cognizance of acts committed by its members which impugn the integrity of a process.
It's an evolving process.
It is not static.
We are currently considering proposals for instance, to impanel grand juries of members on a random basis.
We are proceeding a pace with a self disciplinary process.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Does the record, Mr. Brand, tell us whether the Congress has given any consideration to whether any action should be taken against former congressman Helstoski?

turn.speaker: stanley_mbrand
turn.label: Mr. Stanley M.Brand
turn.text: No sir.
And I would leave with this thought that the Solicitor has indicated in his brief that the Congress can't do both, they can't discipline appropriately and also legislate.

I believe the record is clear that we can discipline with justice through law that we can do it with due process that we can do it with the full panoply of protections and shields that apply in a criminal case, witness the material we've submitted for the record on that.
Thank you.

section.heading: Argument of Wade H. McCree, Jr.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Very well Mr. Brand.
Mr. Solicitor General.

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice, and may it please the Court.

In June 1976, respondent was indicted in the United States District Court for the District of New Jersey on several charges arising out of grand jury investigations into alleged corruption in connection with private immigration legislation.

Count one charged him as a member of Congress with conspiracy to violate the official bribery statute, that's 18 U.S.C. Section 201 (c) (1), by acting with Albert Defalco, his former administrative aid and others, to solicit and to receive bribes in return for being influenced to introduce private bills in the House of Representatives.
13 overt acts in furtherance to the conspiracy were alleged.

These overt acts consisted of charges that respondent and his administrative aid met with attorneys who specialize in immigration litigation and from whom they received cash payments in return for being influenced to introduce private bills for named aliens.
The other three overt acts with which we're concerned here, 2, 3 and 4 also allege the actual introduction of such bills.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: In your view Mr. Solicitor General, for the Government to sustain a case needn't prove anymore than that the money was taken and the promise to do a future act was made?

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: That's --

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Does -- in other words, does it need to prove that the bargain was fulfilled?

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: That's precisely the Government's position, if the Court please.

The offense was to solicit bribes to perform an official act and the offense is complete once the bribe is solicited and it is unnecessary to show that an official act was in fact done in response to it.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Would the crime be consummated if the solicitation were shown but no payment were shown?
Suppose the person solicited refused to pay.

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: The act, if the Court please, it would be under 201 (c) the act is in fact completed when the solicitation is made for the purpose of being influenced.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: But Mr. Solicitor General, I gather -- Judge Meanor said you could not be -- use the evidence of bills, private bills actually being introduced, did he not?

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: That's exactly that --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: And you disagree, don't you?

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: I do not -- we do not disagree with Judge Meanor if a waiver took place.
We agree that Judge Meanor is correct that we could not show the introduction of the bills which is the showing of legislative acts unless a valid waiver occurred.
But we contend --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Heard when and how?

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: We submit that a valid waiver occurred when Mr. Helstoski voluntarily presented voluminous correspondents including copies of the very bills that he introduced after he was told that he needn't -- that he was not required to do that.
And he did it voluntarily and as Judge Meanor found, he knew of his speech or debate privilege when he did it.
Although it was not called directly to his attention, he had raised this privilege in other litigation involving the alleged abuse of the franking privilege.

And in fact in his penultimate appearance before the grand jury, he also invoked the Speech or Debate privilege, and so Judge Meanor's finding that he knew it is amply supported and the U.S. attorney told him that he did not have to submit these matters.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, the -- but -- just so I had it clear, but absent the waiver you agree that under Brewster in irrelevant cases and under the clause, you could not introduce the evidence that you proposed to introduce?

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: We do.
We concede this.
As a matter of fact the -- I'd like to move perhaps right on to the nature of the evidence that is involved here.
We think that this evidence falls into three categories.
First, the bills themselves which as I've just responded are clearly legislative acts, evidence of legislative acts and absent a waiver, we agree that we could not introduce those.
There's a second category of evidence and this consists of correspondence between Helstoski, Defalco, some of the attorneys who represented some of the aliens and some of the aliens themselves.
Now we submit that these evidence has to be examined by the District Court on an item by item basis to see whether it --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: I suppose it refers --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Pardon me?

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: -- it corresponds -- suppose -- as I read some of this, some of these correspondents says, “I did this” or “I didn't do that” in connection with the given private bill.

turn.speaker: stanley_mbrand
turn.label: Mr. Stanley M.Brand
turn.text: Well,

section.heading: Rebuttal of Wade H. McCree, Jr.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Would that be within this category?

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: No, we believe that that is not barred from evidence because --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Even though it refers to something he did or didn't do --

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: Even though it refers --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: -- that could be --

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: -- to something he did or didn't do because --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Even though while he says he did or didn't do would've been a legislative act.

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: Exactly, but he may not have done it.
If there's a letter saying, “If you give me a certain sum of money, I will cause a private bill to be introduced for you.”
This is clearly not a legislative act.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: So you say that under -- that Brewster it would not require exclusion of a promise to introduce a bill in return for money?

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: As I read Brewster, Brewster would not require its exclusion because it relates --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Well what if -- Mr. Solicitor General, the exclusion, I introduced the private bill on your behalf on such and such a date?

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: Well, I assume that as -- let us assume that that's a false statement that he did not in fact introduce a private bill, but he said this for the purpose of eliciting a payment.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: And suppose he did though?

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Suppose he didn't --

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: Well, --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: -- introduce the --

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: If it were introduced for the purpose of showing that he did in fact introduce the bill, I would agree with the Court.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Well, --

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Could that --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Will be excluded then but --

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: No, but suppose --

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: I would agree that they would be excluded, yes.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Suppose was introduced to prove the case that he took money for doing -- for a legislative act or for an official act?

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: We submit that it's admissible that the Court should find that it's admissible for that purpose because soliciting a bribe is clearly and concededly not in a legislative act.
And whatever inducement he may employ for the purpose of soliciting the bribe can not therefore a legislative act and that that is not forbidden by the Speech or Debate Clause.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: But Mr. Solicitor General it isn't forbidden by the District Court order either is it, if it's a future -- if you're talking about the future?

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: If the Court please, that is the way I read that and we would suggest that the past-future dichotomy is not a valid one.

We submit that the Court is -- the District Court was too restrictive because under the old Hillman case for example, a statement of a present intention to do something in the future can be the basis for a finding that it was in fact done.
And so we think logically, the Court should've -- should not even have made the past-future dichotomy and should've said that in both instances, evidence would be admissible.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: But as I understood your comment a moment ago you said a letter assumed by the Congressman he wrote to someone said, “If you give me X dollars, I will introduce such and such a bill.”
And you said, “That would be reference to a future act that may or may not ever be performed.”

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: Exactly.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: And would therefore be admissible or should be admissible and as I understand it, that's admissible under the District Court's --

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: This is also my understanding and --

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: And --

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: -- but the district judge --

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: But then you said --

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: -- said that the reference to the past --

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Right, that a question is --

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: -- is not.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Could such a letter be admissible if it said, “You will recall that two months ago you gave me $500.00 and I introduced such and such a bill in exchange for that.”
Now would that --

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: If --

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: -- letter be admissible?

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: We submit that it would because that statement might be false, and if he said that for the purpose of eliciting a further payment and he had not in fact introduced a bill, he wouldn't be (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: I see, do not offer -- or the truth of the matter asserted in the letter?

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: Exactly.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: General McCree, I suggest you that my earlier colloquy with Mr. Stavis is not entirely irrelevant to some of the questions that my Brother have been asking you.

This is a very hypothetical situation we're presented with and I take it you agree that the jurisdiction of this Court exist by virtue of 28 U.S.C. 1254 that the case was in the Court of Appeals and we therefore have jurisdiction to review it.

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: We do and we concede however that unless the Court of Appeals had jurisdiction that this Court does not have jurisdiction.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: And the only way the Court of Appeals had jurisdiction was pursuant to 18 U.S.C.3731?

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: Exactly and we contend that this is an order suppressing evidence under 3731, and as such it's appealable if the appeal were taken before the defendant was placed in jeopardy.

And we submit that the provision itself admonishes us to give it a liberal construction to effectuate its purposes that is to allow the Government to have a ruling before a defendant is placed in jeopardy.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Do you think the Government could come in and on its own without the defendant making any motion to say, “This is the evidence we're going to present at trial, we'd like the trial court to rule on whether it will be admissible or not.”
And the trial court divides it into categories and said, “This will be admissible, this isn't.”
And the Government can then appeal, say that Court's determination that certain evidence is hearsay and were therefore be inadmissible?

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: That's a difficult question, if the Court please.
An order in (Inaudible) which is really what it is, indicating what evidence might or might not be introduce is admissible under some systems or procedure.
Now whether the federal rules or criminal procedure permit it, I can't direct the Court's attention to a specific provision.
But in this case the Court did and the Court had the matter properly before it on the -- on Mr. Helstoski's motion to dismiss.
Then Mr. Helstoski raised several questions about the evidence and the Court in its ruling, in fact in its first ruling, its our ruling, it said that we would have to redact the indictment.

But in a subsequent written opinion it indicated that we didn't have to redact the indictment but that as the Court has already pointed out, we could show evidence of promises to perform future legislative acts, but not past ones.

And so we submit that the Court did in fact suppress evidence, and we suggest that although this Court hasn't decided the question, there are a number of decisions in the Courts of Appeals which have done exactly this.
One case that I recall is Batiste versus the United States, in which the Sixth Circuit decided that.
And another one in which the -- this Court denied certiorari, that's United States versus Craig from the Seventh Circuit.

We suggest that the Speech or Debate Clause creates immunity for a Congressman from civil or criminal liability for his legislative acts and we concede that it shouldn't be construed as narrowly as just a speech or a debate in the Congress, but that it's the kind of act that's generally done in furtherance of a legislative process which certainly doesn't include soliciting a bribe.
And so we say that there is an immunity for prosecution for a legislative act.
We further submit that the Court has developed an evidentiary privilege, an implementation of this immunity.
