And as the Court has done with the other privileges, evidentiary privileges that it has created, that we suggest that the shield should not be any roader than is necessary to protect the interest for which it was established.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: And all was waivable I gather?

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: I beg your pardon?

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: All was waivable?

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: And we suggest too that it is waivable.
And in this respect of course there isn't any question but that Mr. Helstoski made a gesture before the grand jury of a clean breast of everything.
“I want the grand jury to know that I have nothing to hide” and he brought in all of these materials although he was told that he was not required to do this.
And to permit him to do this and then to assert a privilege would be to make a mockery our off the privilege because he would just have it one way and not both ways.
And the Court does not permit that in other matters and we see no reason why it should in this matter.
We'd also like to suggest that there's another reason why the district -- why this indictment is good and why the District Court's restriction on evidence should be reversed.

We advanced the theory in Brewster that was suggested in Johnson that if there were a narrowly statute, narrowly drawn to achieve the end of regulating the conduct of its business, that the Congress could then involve the executive branch and the judicial branch in it's -- in the discipline of its members.
And we suggest that in Section 201 the Congress has done exactly that in its definition of who is an official.

For the purpose of Section 201, it specifically provides that a member of the Congress is, and then it specifically sets forth the offenses which the defined officials cannot -- I'm -- may, of which they may be found guilty.
So clearly, this is a statute narrowly drawn to achieve the end of regulating the conduct of its members.
And we suggest that there's a good reason for it too.

And my brother who was arguing here a few moments ago suggested or stated in response to a question from the Court that a jury wouldn't be available if a member of the Congress was called on for trial.
The Congress has decided that for this purpose with the third branch involvement there will be a jury, there can be confrontation, right of counsel.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Not only that there can, there must be.

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: There must be, I thank the Court for the correction.
There must be.
And we submit that the Congress has indeed done this with a carefully drawn statute which distinguishes it from Johnson.
This Court didn't address this question in Brewster although the Government briefed it.
But we suggest that this is another basis for arriving at the result that we request.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Mr. Solicitor General, may I be sure I understand your -- you're suggesting in substance, as I understand it that Congress can waive the privilege in certain limited areas, is that right?

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: We do.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Could they pass a statute that says members may be questioned about banking legislation or members may be questioned about legislation dealing with any other specific subject in which perhaps a minority of the Congress might be vitally interested and the majority might not be interested?

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: I think these are clearly legislative acts and I would have difficulty with that, my --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: If they can't waive in that situation how can they waive here?

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: Well there -- what they are doing is asserting that members may be tried for non-legislative acts, which is what we have here, the soliciting of a bribe.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Then if you -- they'd have a non-legislative act, you don't need the waiver, as I understand --

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: Well this is really in response to the argument that the Congress has exclusive jurisdiction of the disciplining of its members.
And we don't think that we have to labor that because we think if the Court is to agree with his argument there, it would have to reverse Brewster.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, --(Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: -- we don't understand --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: I thought your position was that with a narrowly drawn statute, Congress could authorize the prosecution of Congressman for the performance of legislative acts.

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: No.
If the Court please, I did not mean to give that impression, if I did I stand corrected.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, then what relevance is your argument in this case then --

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: Well, this is just --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: -- at this point.

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: -- this is just a second argument why the Congress with a narrowly drawn statute could involve the executive branch and the judicial branch in the disciplining of its members.
In addition to the argument that prevailed in Brewster, identifying the act is a non-legislative act, the taking of the bribes.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: So you're just saying that Congress with a narrowly drawn statute could authorize the executive to end -- to punish a Congressman for conduct falling outside the Speech or Debate Clause?

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: Exactly.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: That's as far as you --

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: That is as far as that argument goes.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: And this argument -- and it also -- so that this argument doesn't affect whether or not this evidence is admissible?

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: Only in this sense that since this is a non-legislative act, evidence --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, --

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: -- soliciting a bribe, evidence can be introduced in support of it.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Yes, as long as if you're right on that, if you're right on that maybe.
But if the Court thought that this involved evidence or conduct protected by Speech or Debate Clause, your argument then would fall by the wayside?

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: We would have to go to our waiver argument.
It would fall by the wayside and only a waiver would permit a prosecution for that.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: And so you at least say then that the privilege or the immunity belongs to the member individually?

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: On in -- it was referred -- with respect to the waiver we do.
And we suggest that we it would be --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Yes but it also is -- it's something that Congress can't waive for him?

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: We suggest -- that the entire Congress?

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: Well, superficial --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: I just asked you if Congress could by a narrowly drawn statute authorize the prosecution for a legislative act, and you said no.

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: Yes, that's correct and I will not retreat from that position.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: So that the --

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: And I'm suggesting that --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: -- privilege does belong to the individual.

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: It belongs to the individual.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: It does indeed.

And I suggest that to allow an individual to have it both ways is contrary to our whole system of jurisprudence that if he doesn't claim, if he does expressly waive, clearly we think he can be prosecuted.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: But he -- but in this case, I don't see -- is there some evidence that he consented to be prosecuted for a legislative act?

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: No he did not expressly waive, but we have this --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Not, no did he ever consent to be prosecuted for a legislative act?

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: He did not consent to be prosecuted for a legislative act.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Do we need to decide in this case whether Congress could by a very statute more narrowly drawn perhaps than Section 201 submit to the trial for a legislative acts, do we need to decide that here?

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: We need not because the act here, soliciting for a bribe is clearly and concededly not a legislative act.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: But the case could be decided narrowly on the basis of Brewster and Johnson?

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: We believe that it can, but we believe that --

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Either way apparently, if I -- you listen to the other side.

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: Well, we believe however that Judge -- that the Court of Appeals was too restrictive and that Judge Meanor was too restricted -- restrictive and this Court should reverse that decision of the Third Circuit to --

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Well, there's another alternative, isn't there and that is to let them go their way and see what happens?

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: That is another course that's available to the Court too.

But we think that the district judge could benefit from the guidance of this Court in indicating what was referred to in Brewster as Acts relating to legislative acts and not legislative acts themselves.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Well I gather Mr. Solicitor General that the Government thinks it has a case even without the materials that Judge Meanor sought that it would exclude it.

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: We believe that --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: (Voice Overlap) enough to get to the jury.

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: We believe the Government has such a case and we have filed with the Court a sealed appendix that I think contains sufficient evidence to go to the jury, but we would like to take the strongest case we can.

My Brother didn't speak about his mandamus action and at least that aspect of it there was a basis for the Court of Appeals denial of his petition and we think that the Court of Appeals was clearly right there.
And unless the Court has any questions about that, I would not discuss that in argument here.
If the Court please, then that concludes the argument of the Government in this manner.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Thank you Mr. Solicitor General.Do you have anything further Mr. Stavis?

turn.speaker: morton_stavis
turn.label: Mr. Morton Stavis
turn.text: Yes I do.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: You have about three minutes left.

turn.speaker: morton_stavis
turn.label: Mr. Morton Stavis
turn.text: Alright, thank you very much.
Picking up the colloquy between the -- Mr. Justice White and Solicitor General, it seems now to be conceded that the Congress cannot waive into an Article III Court trial of a legislative act.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Well, I didn't -- it could --

turn.speaker: morton_stavis
turn.label: Mr. Morton Stavis
turn.text: I cannot believe --

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: If you understood it that way, I didn't.

turn.speaker: morton_stavis
turn.label: Mr. Morton Stavis
turn.text: I think that was what the Solicitor General --

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: He -- I thought he has said Congress has not done that up to now.

turn.speaker: morton_stavis
turn.label: Mr. Morton Stavis
turn.text: I thought he went further.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: I asked him that, whatever is -- that you have to -- that was my question anyway whether if --

turn.speaker: morton_stavis
turn.label: Mr. Morton Stavis
turn.text: I thought --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: -- his answer was that it's another matter.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Do we need to decide whether what Congress could do in the future?

turn.speaker: morton_stavis
turn.label: Mr. Morton Stavis
turn.text: I understand that.
I understand that you don't have to decide this question, but I thought I heard the Solicitor General conceding that.

If I'm wrong, I'd respectfully request to be excused for this error, but if I am right then what the Solicitor General is saying is that while the whole body of Congress can't waive into an Article III Court one member can.
And it just seems to me that that falls of its own way.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Could there --

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Why didn't (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: -- (Voice Overlap) anything that Congress could not do to waive your rights or my rights which you or I individually might well do.

turn.speaker: morton_stavis
turn.label: Mr. Morton Stavis
turn.text: But not when the rights relate to the jurisdiction of a Court.
I can't waive myself into this Court, that's one of the points that Mr. Justice Rehnquist suggested.
We can't, by the fact that I may not even cross-petition.
I can't waive the objection to the jurisdiction of the Third Circuit.
And if this is jurisdictional then the waiver argument doesn't apply either with respect to Congress as a whole or with respect to an individual member of the Congress.
Now, I would like if I may to approach for a moment --

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Well, then let's test that Mr. Stavis.

turn.speaker: morton_stavis
turn.label: Mr. Morton Stavis
turn.text: Sir.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Supposing the Congressman is called before a grand jury.
He's alone in the grand jury room and a bunch of questions are asked of him, but that all of which pertain to legislative acts, he could answer those couldn't he?

turn.speaker: morton_stavis
turn.label: Mr. Morton Stavis
turn.text: He not only could answer them, but if he is not the target I believe he is required to answer.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Assume he's the target?

turn.speaker: morton_stavis
turn.label: Mr. Morton Stavis
turn.text: Well, if he's --

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: He still could answer them if he decides I think I'll answer these questions.

turn.speaker: morton_stavis
turn.label: Mr. Morton Stavis
turn.text: If he is the target and if he answers then he is probably subject to discipline by the House.
But he of course, he can --

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: I mean, for waiving his cons -- his privilege, you say, that (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: morton_stavis
turn.label: Mr. Morton Stavis
turn.text: I respectfully suggest to you that you look at Jefferson's manual which is recorded in our brief in which he says, “Yes, he may not waive that privilege of the House of speech or debate.
But even if the House should overlook that and he has waived it then he has testified -- he has testified.
The next question is, what's the consequence of that testimony?
Does that waive him into an Article III Court when the constitution says the Article III Court has no jurisdiction?
I've never been able to go to a courthouse and say, “Please take this case even though you don't have jurisdiction.”

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: But isn't the grand jury in an Article III Court?

turn.speaker: morton_stavis
turn.label: Mr. Morton Stavis
turn.text: The grand jury is partially in an Article III Court that --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Partially?

turn.speaker: morton_stavis
turn.label: Mr. Morton Stavis
turn.text: Partially, as it's also I think something else too.
I think it's an honor of the executive.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well Mr. Stavis, there's no evidence here that --

turn.speaker: morton_stavis
turn.label: Mr. Morton Stavis
turn.text: I've been lit up but if I --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: morton_stavis
turn.label: Mr. Morton Stavis
turn.text: -- I'd like to add (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: There's no evidence here that he -- that even if a Congressman appear before the grand jury and freely talked about legislative acts, made no objection whatsoever, if he didn't go on and say, “I also waive my immunity from prosecution for a legislative act”, he wouldn't have waived his immunity from prosecution.

turn.speaker: morton_stavis
turn.label: Mr. Morton Stavis
turn.text: Of course not, and he never even said --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: There isn't any evidence like that here.

turn.speaker: morton_stavis
turn.label: Mr. Morton Stavis
turn.text: Not in the slightest, not in the slightest.
May I have 30 seconds?
And then he --

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: We'll give you 60.

turn.speaker: morton_stavis
turn.label: Mr. Morton Stavis
turn.text: Thank you very much Your Honor.
I want to focus on my case in just a moment and that is the indictment.
And particularly on what may be attractive to some of the members of the Court which is, “Well let's just fix up this indictment.”
And I simply want to say that the consequence of that is that you remove the effective operation of the Speech and Debate Clause at the point where it's most important namely where it is accusatory.
Now in Kilbourn against Thompson that used the meaning of the term questioning was not Mr. Justice Stevens' in terms of do you ask a question.

It is rather, may you make a charge.And I respectfully refer you to Mr. Justice Miller's opinion in which he equates the Speech or Debate Clause the term questioning to the language of the Massachusetts constitution which refers to accusation.

If you take that concept and then move over to Mr. Justice Rehnquist's question and say, “Is there any case where you set aside an indictment because there's something that happened in the grand jury?”
And I say that that's exactly what you do in the immunity type case where a grand jury heard testimony that was barred from him, they shouldn't have heard him.
And you say to that prosecutor, “Well if you did it, we cancel that indictment.
If you want to go ahead and not use that prohibited testimony, you're free to do so.”
And that's all we've ever said here, and if the prosecutor should decide not to do that, in any event we said that the Congress has jurisdiction.
And I'm very grateful to you, Your Honor, for indulging me to that extent.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Thank you gentlemen.
The case is submitted.
